name: Constanze Roedig
bio:
Key Researcher & Lecturer, Public Speaker, Creator of the Software Bill of Behavior (SBoB) and maintainer of the Kubernetes Storm Center for cloudnative intelligence

Backstory: Living intentionally is hard when routine takes control. I grew up wanting to be a scientist, studying Biochemistry, starting med school, and ultimately earning a PhD in General Relativity to explore how humans perceive 'reality.' When US funding cuts ended that path, I realized academia left me without agency.

In the private sector, I discovered the value of risk. The Cloud Native paradigm let me experiment, fail fast, and try again without fear of lasting damage. In positive-sum collaborations, I saw how my algorithms could shape real-world outcomes, and how taking calculated risks created visible change for people and systems alike. This freedom to test ideas with relatively low cost revealed a new kind of agency, an immediacy and measurable connection to the meaning of work.

My vision is to empower others to leverage cloud native technology with respect for the human element, security, and risk. Because having agency means creating reality for our society, for each one of us, one epsilon at a time.

name: Craig Box
bio:
Craig is Senior Director of Developer Relations at cloud-native application networking company Solo.io, and a Steering Committee member for the Istio project.

Prior to Solo, Craig had a number of roles at Google, including leading Google's participation in Istio, Head of GTM launching GKE, and leader of the Cloud Native developer relations team, responsible for Kubernetes, GKE and Anthos. He was the founder and co-host of the Kubernetes Podcast from Google, producing the top 20 show for over four years.

Craig has worked with Cloud Native customers and communities since the launch of Kubernetes in 2014, and has delivered talks on 6 continents, including a KubeCon keynote. He started his career when DevOps was called ‚Äòsystems administration‚Äô, and has 20 years of experience in development, deployment, DevOps, consulting, advisory and management roles around the world.

name: Cristher Castro
bio:
Cristher Castro, co-founder and COO of Cuemby, is a visionary leader and operational dynamo who drives community building in the Latam tech scene. Over the last 3 years, she advocated for the adoption of open-source technologies within the Spanish-speaking community, creating and supporting tech meetups and events in the region. She co-created, along with her team, the first Kubernetes Community Days in Colombia. This event paved the way for the expansion of Cloud Native Groups throughout the region. Cristher's foresight and operational expertise have been fundamental to the success of both Cuemby and the Cloud Native Latam Group. Recognizing the region's need for in-depth knowledge of cloud-native applications, Cristher championed the LFS250 (Linux Foundation Course) and administered the KCNA certifications donated by CNCF to the region. These two initiatives heightened awareness of cloud-native technologies and certifications, fortifying local proficiency in open-source solutions. She continues to promote and advocate for the recognition of the Cloud Native Computing Foundation (CNCF) in the region, addressing both business and community aspects. Cristher's leadership and operational prowess exemplify her unwavering commitment to fostering a thriving Latam tech community. https://community.cncf.io/cloud-native-latin-america/ https://community.cncf.io/cloud-native-medellin/ https://www.cncf.io/reports/kcd-colombia-2023/ https://www.cuemby.com/about-us https://www.linkedin.com/company/fundaci%C3%B3n-hispana-de-cloud-native/?viewAsMember=true https://community.cncf.io/cloud-native-colombia/ https://www.linkedin.com/showcase/kcd-colombia/?viewAsMember=truehttps://www.linkedin.com/showcase/kcd-colombia

Why I am excited to be an ambassador: Becoming a CNCF ambassador empowers me to further my dedication to community growth in the LATAM region. I deeply believe that the region's success hinges on the symbiotic collaboration of professionals, students, and companies. It's this harmony that forms the core of my mission: to cultivate a thriving community ecosystem centered around open-source and cloud-native technologies. Through this role, I am positioned to amplify awareness about these technologies and the transformative opportunities they introduce. My operational and logistics expertise is set to facilitate more meetups and events, thus kindling the formation of new communities. Collaborating with fellow leaders and ambassadors provides a unique platform to unite our efforts, ensuring we collectively advance our shared vision.

My love affair with Kubernetes stems from its beautiful chaos - where community-driven solutions tackle real-world problems head-on. Think of me as your friendly neighbourhood automation enthusiast, fueled by coffee and powered by faith, always ready to transform complex challenges into elegant solutions. Because in the end, technology is not just about code - it's about building bridges and growing together. Life's journey isn't just about conquering technical challenges; it's about leaving footprints of kindness and knowledge for others to follow. name: Etienne Ehrhardt
bio: After more than ten years of experience in infrastructure and middleware integration in various environments, I've naturally shifted to the cloud native world by more specifically focusing on container platforms. During the last years, I've acquired solid skills in designing and setting up cloud-native oriented architectures relying on various container engines, OpenShift and Kubernetes. The main focus being integrating those complex platforms in on-prem trusted, secured and compliant environments, as well as designing more hybrid setups in AWS and Azure. Those state of the art container platforms bring tremendous agility features to micro services integration, but there are nothing without proper governance and without using the right tools sets depending on a wide range of contexts and use cases. The cloud native world and its vast eco-system is evolving at high pace and today's challenge for many companies is to make sure they're not outrun by this strong wind of change in the digital transformation race. It's furthermore also important to understand all those concepts, the way they interact and their many impacts.

bio:
Humble, a Staff Engineer/Tech Lead at VMware and a dedicated open source advocate for over 17 years, also serves as a Ceph Ambassador. Since 2016, his pivotal role as a core contributor/maintainer to Kubernetes has been instrumental in its ongoing maintenance and evolution. Notably, he initiated the Kubernetes Bangalore meetup, uniting over 8k+ enthusiasts, and assumed an organizational role in the Cloud Native Bangalore chapter. Expanding his influence, in 2019, Humble spearheaded the creation and management of the Kubernetes Kerala Meetup, actively nurturing the Cloud Native community in the region while leading KCD Kerala 2024. His fervor for mentoring and empowering individuals drives his ongoing commitment. Alongside speaking engagements at various conferences, his impactful blogs on Cloud Native technologies underline his expertise. Furthermore, his authorship of "Mastering KVM Virtualization" solidifies his authoritative stance in the field. https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/graphs/contributors https://kcdkerala.in https://community.cncf.io/cloud-native-bangalore/ https://bit.ly/k8sKerala https://bit.ly/k8sBLR https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/container-native-storage-39-enhanced-day-2-management-and-unified-installation-within-openshift-container-platform https://kubernetes.io/blog/2022/09/21/kubernetes-1-25-use-secrets-while-expanding-csi-volumes-on-node-alpha/ https://www.humblec.com/

Why I am excited to be an ambassador: I'm excited to be a CNCF ambassador because it offers a unique opportunity to actively contribute to the world of cloud-native technologies, which is a dynamic and rapidly evolving field. As an ambassador, I can foster collaboration and knowledge sharing among a diverse group of professionals, ultimately advancing the adoption and understanding of cloud-native practices. It's an inspiring role that allows me to be at the forefront of innovation and connect with experts and enthusiasts in the CNCF ecosystem, all while promoting the growth of these transformative technologies.

bio: Jakob possesses a strong affinity for cybersecurity, having held various roles within four distinct Security Operation Centers (SOCs), including Security Engineer, Incident Responder, Incident Response Manager, TriceratOps Automation Manager, and Acting Head of SOC. Utilizing his expertise in blue teaming and passion for red teaming, Jakob contributes to enhancing the cybersecurity posture of both internal and external organizations. His extensive knowledge is complemented by a range of industry-recognized certifications, including OSCP, OSEP, GCFA, GDAT, GSOM, Kubestronaut (CKA, CKS), and others. Jakob's contributions to open-source initiatives have garnered recognition from SANS Institute, a leading authority in cybersecurity research and training. His Sigma rules were referenced by SANS ICS, while his co-authored open-source project (ATC RE&CT) was featured in the SANS MGT551 course. Jakob brings a unique blend of technical expertise and passion for cybersecurity to his work. With a strong educational background in computer science and cybersecurity, Jakob has developed a deep understanding of complex security systems and threats. His dedication to staying at the forefront of industry trends and advancements has earned him a reputation as a knowledgeable and effective cybersecurity expert. Jakob aspires to achieve a pioneering role as the first hacker-CISO within an S&P 500 organization, leveraging his expertise and passion for advancing cybersecurity best practices.

name: James Spurin
bio:
With over 25 years of experience, James Spurin is an industry veteran skilled in various technical fields and adept at leading Engineering teams in top-tier Financial Services organisations. He now focuses on creating online courses and Technical Educational Content in areas such as DevOps, Kubernetes, and Cloud Native, incorporating hands-on learning experiences through container-based lab environments and has reached over 100,000 students globally. As a CNCF Ambassador, James actively advocates for Container and Cloud Native knowledge, education, and Kubernetes-based orchestration. His company, DiveInto, champions Cloud Native and consistently shares fresh content on its YouTube channel: https://youtube.com/DiveInto James has also established an inclusive community dedicated to Cloud Native learning, which can be accessed at https://community.diveinto.com

Why I am excited to be an ambassador: I am excited to be a CNCF Ambassador as it aligns perfectly with my passion for creating technical educational content on Cloud Native/Kubernetes whilst also Giving Back, a core-principle of the CNCF. The role supports me in more actively engaging with a diverse global community, enabling me to learn from others whilst also sharing my own knowledge and expertise. As an Ambassador, I will contribute to thought leadership in the cloud native space and hope to provide an instrumental role in fostering a culture of knowledge sharing, learning and innovation. Throughout this journey, I am also eager to support and encourage others in pursuing CNCF Cloud Native certifications - an endeavour I am both passionate about and an advocate for. Overall, being a CNCF Ambassador is a highly rewarding and fulfilling experience that allows me to give back to the community while staying updated on the latest developments in the field.

Before his open source career, Jonathan spent over a decade in data center infrastructure and co-founded one of the industry's earliest cloud computing companies, which grew into a billion-dollar business following its acquisition by Rackspace. Passionate about open collaboration, infrastructure innovation, and empowering users, contributors, and ecosystems worldwide, Jonathan frequently speaks at international conferences on open source strategy, infrastructure modernization, cloud-native technologies, and open source AI initiatives.

Kasper wrote his master thesis, ‚ÄúKubeCloud - A Small Scale Cloud Computing Environment‚Äù, on how Universities could leverage small-scale cloud environments built out of Raspberry Pis running Kubernetes.

Why I am excited to be an ambassador: I'm excited to be an ambassador, because it's a great community of like-minded people. I hope to meet and learn from the other awesome Ambassadors, and help grow the adoption of Cloud Native technologies even more here in the Nordics.

In 2023, he reviewed the Japanese translation of Learning eBPF, published by O'Reilly Japan. In 2024, he became an organizer of Cloud Native Community Japan (CNCJ), fostering open source culture in Japan. Additionally, he served as Co-Chair of KubeDay Japan 2024, playing a key role in shaping the event and promoting cloud-native technologies within the Japanese developer community.

Recognizing the growing importance of eBPF in cloud-native environments, Kenta founded the eBPF Japan Community for engineers across various industries to collaborate, share knowledge, and drive eBPF adoption in Japan.

name: Konrad Rzentarzewski
bio:
I was there when the config burned.

In the age before observability, chaos reigned. The servers howled, and nothing scaled but entropy.

Then kube cattle were born ‚Äî simple, nameless beasts born of children‚Äôs games. But they multiplied. And their hunger grew vast.

Years passed. The sun revolved the Earth. Then the Earth revolved the Cloud.

I grew tired of debugging in darkness. I longed for light. And logs. Preferably structured. That‚Äôs when I began preaching ‚Äî not loudly, just‚Ä¶ declaratively. One apply at a time.

I walked among DevOps tribes, where bash begat shell, and shell begat pain. To them I brought ConfigMaps, and Secrets hidden in plain sight.

Then came the mysterious YAML ‚Äî a language too holy to lint ‚Äî inscribed deep within the API‚Äôs own heart.

Through toil and merge, the infrastructure became manifest. Pods floated on the waters. Deployments begat replicas. Helm bore Charts. Git begat Ops. What was once dev spun to prod. And every service had a name ‚Äî and every name resolved. Unless external DNS was involved.

And the Preachers said: \"Behold, our logs streameth clean.\"

Thus began the age of the declarative. We once dwelled in darkness. Now, we scale planetary in full light.

name: Lee Calcote
bio:
Lee Calcote is the Founder of Layer5, where the community helps organizations harness and exploit the value of service meshes. He led software-defined data center engineering at Seagate, delivering predictive analytics and modern systems management. Calcote held various leadership positions at Cisco, where he created Cisco‚Äôs cloud management platforms and pioneered new, automated, remote management services.

In addition to his role at Layer5, Calcote serves in various industry bodies, including as a SIG chair in Cloud Native Computing Foundation (CNCF), and formerly, participated in the delivery of Redfish 1.0 in the Distributed Management Task Foundation (DMTF), and Docker Benchmark 1.0 in Center for Internet Security (CIS). He is a startup advisor, Docker Captain, Cloud Native Ambassador, O‚ÄôReilly author, and speaker in the cloud native ecosystem.

Calcote is a maintainer of open source projects, including Meshery, Service Mesh Interface, and Service Mesh Performance. Calcote holds a bachelor‚Äôs degree in Computer Science, a master‚Äôs degree in Business Administration from California State University, Fresno and retains a list of industry certifications.

name: Maximilian Braun
bio:
Maximilian Braun is an Engineering Manager at SAP where he leads a team of cloud native engineers at the forefront of the digital transformation from traditional enterprise IT to modern cloud-native platforms.

He was forged in the human cauldron of DevOps toil (including the genuinely terrifying Friday deployments), emerging with a perspective shaped by Infrastructure-as-Data principles and the DORA metrics ethos. He turned those hard-earned lessons into a philosophy: treat everything as code and data for full reproducibility and auditability, and let key metrics guide continuous improvement. The goal: to banish the fear from deployment days and elevate the developer experience.

Today, his work extends to the broader European technology landscape. He is a workstream lead in the European IPCEI-CIS initiative and a NeoNephos Ambassador, advocating for European interoperability and an ecosystem built together on an open-source digital commons. He also champions multiple CNCF and NeoNephos projects and initiatives with his team.

Looking ahead, Maximilian is focused on helping build a future where European digital sovereignty is not just a concept but a reality - powered by open, interoperable, and community-driven cloud technologies that empower the next generation of developers.

In the fascinating journey of technology exploration, his homelab has flourished, expanding to a scale that rivals the capabilities of some enterprise-level cloud infrastructures.

Why I am excited to be an ambassador: Community propels open source projects to flourish. I'm excited to be an ambassador to help grow the cloud native community by providing mentorship to new contributors, guidance to those starting on their cloud native journey, and amplifying the excitement for cloud native technology.

name: Reynaldo Linares
bio: Reynaldo Linares is a Principal Cloud Engineer at Verizon, specializing in OpenShift and Kubernetes within the Verizon Cloud Platform (VCP) powering 5G Standalone. A lifelong learner and newly accepted Kubestronaut, he shares creative, story-driven Kubernetes education through his project Pods & Clues (podsandclues.com).

name: Rhegisan Jebas
bio: As a seasoned DevOps engineer, I specialize in leveraging automation and cutting-edge tools to streamline processes and enhance efficiency. Off-duty, I'm deeply immersed in cricket and e-gaming, where strategy and precision captivate me just as they do in my professional endeavors. Engaging with cloud communities and conferences keeps me informed on the latest tech trends, enabling me to optimize workflows and share insights effectively.

name: Ribet Thomas
bio: Passionate about IT since forever, I‚Äôve been working in the industry since 2019 with a strong interest in open source, Kubernetes, and cloud-native technologies. Specialized in DevSecOps, automation, and observability, I help teams design secure and scalable solutions. Curious and community-driven, I stay tuned to emerging trends, especially around microservices.

name: Ricardo Aravena
bio: Ricardo is a Cloud Native AI Lead at Snowflake. He's an open source enthusiast, co-chairing the CNCF TAG-Runtime, lead for the Cloud Native AI Working Group and CNCF Ambassador. Recently, he led the publication of the Cloud Native AI Whitepaper and is currently leading various initiatives in the Cloud Native AI Working Group. He has worked in tech and software engineering roles for over 25 years. He comes from a diverse professional background, having held different roles at large companies such as Rakuten, Cisco, and VMware and startups such as Truera, Branch Metrics and Coupa.

name: Ricardo Carrillo Cruz

With 20 years of experience in cloud and automation, he has deep expertise across the full evolution of the industry. He previously worked on the OpenShift Networking and Telco RAN Engineering teams, bringing strong Kubernetes and cloud-native telecommunications knowledge to his work. A dedicated open-source contributor, he served as an OpenStack Infra core contributor and Ansible OpenStack modules maintainer. Outside of work, he's a devoted father who loves spending time with his wife and three kids, traveling, and enjoying good food.

name: Ricardo Molendijk
bio: Mission Critical Engineer from the Netherlands, interested in GovTech. https://ricardomolendijk.com

name: Ricardo Rocha

He has led for several years the internal effort to transition services and workloads to use cloud native technologies, as well as dissemination and training efforts. Ricardo got CERN to join the CNCF and is a lead of the CNCF Research User Group. Prior to this work Ricardo helped develop the grid computing infrastructure serving the Large Hadron Collider (LHC).

name: Riccardo Bertelli

That curiosity pulled me into the world of DevOps, where I instantly fell in love with Docker, Kubernetes, and more recently, NixOS. I‚Äôm passionate about cloud-native technologies, automation, and system design, and I‚Äôm always exploring how to make systems more resilient and elegant. When I‚Äôm not debugging YAML or optimizing CI pipelines, you‚Äôll probably find me explaining to friends why ‚Äújust one more container‚Äù is a perfectly reasonable hobby

name: Riccardo Cannella

As a Platform Architect, I'm fortunate enough to put my passion into the work I do every day, guiding customers in the adoption of cloud-native technologies and helping them with the design of their infrastructure. I love working with CNCF technologies, especially with monitoring tools and automation stacks, and I always look forward to the next conference!

name: Riccardo Capraro

I offer a unique combination of hands-on experience operating high-stakes applications at scale, in different business domains, and a wide breadth of knowledge spanning the whole software lifecycle, from the single line of code up to production operations. I deliver presentations at CNCF events about topics such as Kubernetes operators, Pipeline Design, FluxCD and GitOps,... I co-organise the Vienna DevOps Meetup and soon Cloud Native Trento
location: Trento, Autonomous Province of Trento, Italy

name: Riccardo Menegazzo
bio: I'm an Infrastructure Architect and DevOps Engineer with deep expertise in Kubernetes and cloud-native technologies. I specialize in designing production-grade container orchestration platforms and implementing GitOps workflows across cloud and on-premise environments. I focus on building scalable, secure infrastructure through automation and declarative approaches, with strong emphasis on cost optimization and reliability. A passionate advocate for open-source solutions and continuous learning, I actively engage with the CNCF community and I'm a member of the Cloud Native Days Italy organizing team, staying current with evolving technologies and continuously improving my skills in cloud-native and DevOps practices.

name: Rich Andrews
bio: I started my career as a hardware support engineer, then over the years have progressed through system engineer to now leading an SRE team.

name: Richard Fan
bio: I'm a Security Engineer and cloud enthusiast. I'm passionate about learning new things, especially about Cloud Security. Fascinated by the CNCF Landscape, I started exploring different CNCF projects. I am also an AWS Security Hero. Besides being a Kubestronaut, I'm also proud of my OSCP certificate.

name: Richard Hartmann
bio: Richard "RichiH" Hartmann is the Director of Community at Grafana Labs, Prometheus team member, OpenMetrics founder, OpenTelemetry member, CNCF TAG Observability chair, CNCF Governing Board member, and more. He also leads or organizes various conferences, including PromCon, FOSDEM, DENOG, DebConf, and Chaos Communication Congress. In the past, he made mainframe databases work, ISP backbones run, freenode work, and designed and built a datacenter from scratch. Go through his talks at https://github.com/RichiH/talks or follow him on Twitter at https://twitter.com/TwitchiH for musings on the intersection of technology and society.

name: Richard Kooij
bio: Astronomer turned Kubestronaut. Experienced in event driven, microservices architecture - all cloud-native.

name: Richard Phan Chan The
bio: I am an enthusiastic and hardworking IT professional, I have a strong Linux background, strong skills in system administration and automation, deep knowledge of microservices and Kubernetes

name: Richard Steinbiss
bio: Richard brings over seven years of consulting experience from Umlaut (part of Accenture) and Detecon (part of Deutsche Telekom), where he leveraged his data analytics and engineering skills to assist international clients in telecommunications and other industries. He holds a Master's degree with honors in Information and Communications Technology from RWTH Aachen University in Germany. Fully certified in Azure, AWS, and of course Kubernetes, Richard manages the data analytics and machine learning initiatives at OnRamp, a global fintech startup.

name: Richard ≈†ufliarsky

Some of the key tools and projects we rely on include ArgoCD, Harbor, Tekton, Kaniko, Grafana + Loki + Mimir + Alloy, Linstor + Piraeus Operator, Ceph + Rook, Cilium, Proxmox, Metacontroller, MetalLB, and cert-manager.

name: Rick Geerts
bio:
[rick ~]$ vim About

Founder of Digital Athletes. Consultant with a strong DevOps mindset. Actively working with open-source, container, orchestrator, cloud, and automation technologies. Open-minded and always eager to learn. In my spare time, I tinker around on my homelab, which I use to self-host applications (automated as much as possible) and try out new technologies.

:wq

name: Ricky Waldt
bio: One year ago, I left my Project Manager role to start from zero in tech. Completed a 5-month DevOps traineeship in 3,5 months. Landed my first job as a Jr. DevOps Consultant 2 months later. Became the first "Kubestronaut" in my company. Today, a family man with a steady income, company car, I love my wife, my job, my life, and I switched hobbies from playing Xbox to learning how to build a HomeLab. Who knows, I may end up installing Kubernetes on my Xbox Series S.

name: Rim Ben Nasr
bio: I‚Äôm leading a transformation of the company‚Äôs infrastructure, driving the initiative to democratize building on top of Kubernetes and using the technologies around it. I‚Äôm part of building a platform that is easy enough to make it obvious to use. What I love most is using technology to serve the human and help you become a better person in your work and in your life.

name: Rim Dammak
bio: My name is Rim Dammak, a cloud-native enthusiast, currently working at HPE. Feel free to connect with me on LinkedIn if you‚Äôd like to collaborate or discuss topics related to the CNCF ecosystem.

name: Rio Kierkels
bio: I started in Visual Effects and Film, which sparked my fascination with large computer systems. Now, armed with a master's in Security and Network Engineering, my mission is to make technology work better for everyone. I design systems that are not only fast and secure but also easy and enjoyable to use. I love sharing what I've learned, helping wherever I can, and speaking about my work.

name: Rishabh Jain

His expertise encompasses container orchestration platforms including Kubernetes, Amazon ECS, and Amazon EKS. As a certified public speaker and key member of the Containers focus area, he continues to contribute to the cloud computing community through knowledge sharing and technical leadership.

name: Rishabh Sharma

He is currently responsible to implement and manage Kubernetes solution for 4G and 5G technologies. He is interested to be the contributor to Kubernetes. His other key areas of interest are Java, Spring-Boot, Containerd, Linux, Istio, Linkerd, Falco, Sysdig, CoreDNS, Helm, OPA (Open Policy Agent), Cilium, Envoy etc. He is the first Kubestronaut from FINLAND.

name: Rishabh Singh

In 2019, I began my Kubernetes journey, and since then have been actively using the technology. In my current role, I work as an SME for Azure Kubernetes Service.

name: Rishat Azizov
bio: Cloud Engineer, Linux system administrator. Electric car fan, subscribe to my channel: https://t.me/zeroemissions :)

name: Rishit Dagli

He also maintains/contributes extensively to popular open-source projects like TensorFlow, PyTorch, Kubernetes, and Kubeflow among others and also frequently works on building new open-source projects. You will also often find him speaking at a CNCF conference.

name: Roach A

With hands-on expertise in Argo CD, Istio, Prometheus, Grafana, and CI/CD pipelines, I enable secure, automated, and production-grade cloud-native ecosystems. As a proud Kubestronaut, I bring strong depth across platform engineering and DevSecOps. Passionate about cloud-native innovation and the emerging role of GenAI in DevOps/SRE, I embrace challenges as opportunities to grow.

name: Rob Kenefeck
bio: I've been Automating toil in Linux for over 20 years, but when Kubernetes came along I was initially dismissive, after all I was already building everything in Containers with Docker and orchestrating in a variety of semi-manual ways. I've since come to appreciate all Kubernetes can do and also what its limitations are and when NOT to use it. I've taught DevOps courses and Kubernetes courses while also helping large enterprises setup internally managed Kubernetes platforms with a product based mindset. I believe that security is so fundamental to everything that we do, we shouldn't be shoving it in as an afterthought with DevSecOps. Now, you'll find me at Cloud Native Melbourne (or almost any other Kubernetes/Platform Engineering meetup in Melbourne), organising CloudCon AU or spruiking Toastmasters. I'll be virtually present in FINOS Common Cloud controls or the APAC Security and Cpmpliance TAG

name: Rob Kenefeck
bio: I've been Automating toil in Linux for over 20 years, but when Kubernetes came along I was initially dismissive, after all I was already building everything in Containers with Docker and orchestrating in a variety of semi-manual ways. I've since come to appreciate all Kubernetes can do and also what its limitations are and when NOT to use it. I've taught DevOps courses and Kubernetes courses while also helping large enterprises setup internally managed Kubernetes platforms with a product based mindset. I believe that security is so fundamental to everything that we do, we shouldn't be shoving it in as an afterthought with DevSecOps

name: Rob Maas
bio: As Field CTO at ON2IT, I‚Äôm dedicated to helping organizations strengthen their security posture by adopting Zero Trust as a core strategy. With extensive expertise in cybersecurity, I provide technical leadership across a wide range of platforms, ensuring seamless integration of advanced security principles into modern IT environments. My work frequently involves cloud and cloud-native solutions. I‚Äôm passionate about empowering businesses to navigate complex security challenges, combining strategic insight with hands-on technical expertise to drive innovation and resilience in the face of cyber threats.

name: Rob Mokkink
bio: Technical Architect for Openshift/Kubernetes platform for a large government organisation. I like working with the broad eco system and solutions for kubernetes. Where i can help i will participate in projects and contribute code.

name: Rob Owens
bio: I'm a Senior DevOps Engineer, focused on building systems and platform that make mine and other's lives easier. I'm always looking for more things to try out and new things to learn, especially when it comes to technology. I have a large passion for the Kubernetes platform and all of the projects that are part of the CNCF.

name: Robert Klonner
bio: I am a DevOps engineer passionate about automation and GitOps - striving for continuous improvement of processes and environments. I am always eager to learn new technologies and for that, the CNCF landscape provides a lot of exciting projects to discover.

name: Robert Markolwitz
bio: Back in 2009, when I was working in product management and marketing for a German IT company, I started to become heavily interested in what makes the internet work the way it does. I devoted a great deal of my free time to teach myself about networking and programming, developing just enough skills and confidence to eventually change careers and pursue software development for a living. Since 2012 I have earned my stripes as software engineer and for the last 6 years designed, created and maintained Kubernetes based architectures in multi-tenancy environments, crafted a fair share of CI/CD-Pipelines on various different platforms, managed application deployments (leveraging both, best-practices and, in hindsight, not-so-good practices), implemented automations to streamline workflows and overall helped development teams to ship their products faster and reliable, all while keeping a watchful eye on security. I do not hold any degree in CS but I am equipped with unstoppable drive to eventually ‚Äûfigure things out‚Äú. Currently I am working as a consultant, guiding and assisting clients to adopt cloud native technologies and to build, maintain and operate cloud (Azure) and hybrid infrastructures.

name: Robert Muller
bio: DevOps engineer with a passion for resilient infrastructure and a relentless drive to automate everything that can be automated. I‚Äôve spent the last decade building, automating, and securing Kubernetes platforms across cloud, hybrid-cloud, and on-premise environments. From Terraform modules to Helm charts, I enjoy making complex systems work simply and reliably.

name: Robert Sirchia
bio: I create content around CNCF projects, building enablement content around CNCF projects. I help contribute around marketing and community efforts with CNCF projects. I am a new code contributor to a CNCF project

name: Robert Volkmann
bio: As an experienced and passionate Cloud Native Architect, I accelerate my clients' Private Cloud journeys by designing and implementing customized, high-performance, and secure on-premise bare-metal Kubernetes platforms. I leverage my technical expertise in CNCF technologies to guide cross-functional teams in orchestrating implementation strategies, optimizing system performance, and driving scalable cloud-native solutions. Additionally, I promote the long-term success and sustainability of the infrastructure by providing tailored training for employees.

name: Roberth Strand
bio:
I am a self-proclaimed "cloud automator", and I work at Sopra Steria based out of Oslo, Norway. I have been granted the title of Microsoft MVP for my work with Azure, and I have been an active contributor in the CNCF for which I earned the title Cloud Native Ambassador. I initiated Cloud Native Norway, a non-profit that works to build up and enable Cloud Native adoption and development in Norway. I also co-founded the Azure Cloud Native User Group, and founded the Norwegian PowerShell User Group. In the CNCF, I have been active for years in TAG App Delivery, and currently serves as co-chair for the TAG, maintainer on the OpenGitOps project, and as co-chair of the Platforms Working Group.

Why I am excited to be an ambassador: For many years, the CNCF has continued to impress me. The way that the foundation has supported the community and the projects is truly admirable. Even though I have other honorary titles, the CNCF Ambassador title is one that I value very much. While I don't do community work for the titles, I am happy for the recognition. I have big plans for my work in the CNCF, and I look forward to seeing how the ambassador program will help me achieve more for the community.

Sessionize: https://sessionize.com/roberth-strand

name: Roberto Colella
bio:
I'm a Senior Solution Engineer with over ten years of experience in IT, specializing in cloud-native technologies and practices.

My dedication revolves around promoting the adoption of CNCF technologies and contributing to community growth through sharing my knowledge and dedication to open-source projects.

Continuously embracing a beginner's mindset across life's challenges, I proficiently present technical concepts to diverse audiences, dedicated to achieving customer success and nurturing strong relationships.
company: Prisma Cloud by Palo Alto Networks

name: Roberto Fernande Da Silva
bio: Roberto is a Solutions Architect at AWS, with a strong focus on the financial sector. His journey with Kubernetes started back in 2018, during his first KubeCon in Seattle ‚Äî an experience that marked the beginning of a deep, ongoing relationship with cloud-native technologies. Since then, he‚Äôs been helping clients across the maturity spectrum: from those launching their very first cluster, to enterprises managing hundreds of clusters who are scaling governance, resilience, and innovation through platform engineering. After hard work, the reward is not just rest ‚Äî it's growth. That mindset drives Roberto: continuously learning, sharing knowledge, and helping teams architect systems that are not only scalable, but sustainable. Whether building from scratch or evolving mature platforms, he‚Äôs passionate about turning complexity into clarity ‚Äî and creating a Kubernetes-powered future, one cluster at a time.

name: Roberto Galaz Alvarado
bio: DevOps Engineer at Veritas Automata, specializing in Kubernetes and cloud-native technologies, with a focus on automation, infrastructure as code, and Rust development

name: Roberto Gomez
bio: I am a Solutions Architect specializing in IT automation with VMware Aria Automation (now VCF Automation) and VMware Tanzu. Coming from the world of virtualization, and making my way as a DevOps / SRE.

name: Roberto Magallanes
bio: Engineer passionate about technology and innovation, specializing in CNCF technologies such as Kubernetes, Docker, and Prometheus.

name: Roberto Tagliabue
bio: I'm a Senior Cloud Solution Architect specializing in AWS technologies. I work extensively with EKS clusters and am familiar with many CNCF projects. My favorites are Argo CD, Kyverno, and Karpenter. I'm deeply interested in Kubernetes world and continuous learning and enjoy exploring innovative solutions to improve cloud architectures and automation.

name: Robin Peerlinck
bio: Cloud-Native & Platform Consultant with a strong DevOps mindset and a deep interest in Kubernetes and CNCF technologies. I design and build secure, scalable platforms with a strong focus on platform engineering, integration, and secure software supply chains. Driven by curiosity and a pragmatic approach, I enjoy exploring new tools and open-source projects to improve how teams build and operate software. Always up for exchanging ideas over a good beer or a quality coffee.

name: Robin Smorenburg
bio:
Hello! I'm Robin Smorenburg, a passionate technologist with an eye for detail who turned his passion for technology into a career. Throughout my career, I‚Äôve become a respected thought leader in the industry, sharing my knowledge and expertise with others, being recognized by Microsoft, and receiving the Microsoft Most Valuable Professional or MVP Award in the Azure category. With Kevin Evans, I run the StreamingClouds live stream, where we engage with inspiring individuals‚Äîour industry‚Äôs thought leaders‚Äîspreading positivity and sharing their knowledge and advice. And the StreamingClouds Community is a safe place where we‚Äôre helping each other, supported by a fantastic group of moderators we can call friends.

Why I am excited to be an ambassador: I‚Äôm really excited about joining the CNCF on the mission of "making cloud native ubiquitous". Enhancing my efforts of leading by example, inspiring and helping as many people as possible while being open and inclusive, and treating everyone with the utmost respect. Making a difference through community building and mentoring, impacting the lives of others, leveling the playing field, and fostering community collaboration and relationships. And last but not least, the technologist in me loves cloud-native!

name: Robin Werner
bio: With over two years of experience in leadership roles at Pexon Consulting GmbH, I am responsible as Head of Azure for expanding our Azure portfolio and supporting direct clients in presales. My focus is on developing modern cloud strategies, with a focus in Kubernetes. In the past, I have led numerous cloud projects, built strategic partnerships, and conducted workshops and training sessions. Innovation, customer orientation, and continuous learning are at the core of my approach.

name: Robisson Oliveira
bio: I have been working in software development for 17 years, and for the past 10 years I have focused on developing distributed systems. I am currently a Senior Application Architect at Amazon Web Services, focused on resilience and the design of large-scale applications.

name: Robson Franco
bio: IT professional with a 15-year career, currently fueled by challenges and opportunities of Cloud Computing.

name: Roby Chen
bio:
I am honored to continue serving in this role. Over the past few years, My company DaoCloud has made continuous contributions to the open-source community. Our contributions to Kubernetes, a core cloud-native project, have ranked among the top three globally over the past year. In 2022, we will also take on a contributing seat on Istio's steering committee. We have independently open-sourced nine projects, including Clusterpedia, Merbridge and Piraeus which have successfully entered CNCF Sandbox incubation. DaoCloud continues to contribute significantly towards cloud-native technology and improve CNCF's technical ecosystem.

Why I am excited to be an ambassador: Firstly, I hope that cloud-native technology will remain highly connected to China, and that the integration of the technology world will not be affected by geography, politics, international conflicts and other factors. Secondly, I hope that cloud-native technology can break through the barriers between technology and users, and that more end-user voices can be fed back to CNCF. Thirdly, I hope to promote the building of cloud-native technology talent and further improve the cloud-native education system, so that CNCF will become a sustainable organization.
company: SHANGHAI DAOCLOUD NETWORK TECHNOLOGY CO. LTD. (DAOCLOUD)

name: Rodion Serhieiev
bio: I am a Senior DevOps / Platform Engineer specializing in Kubernetes and cloud-native platforms on AWS and Azure, with a strong MLOps focus. I design and operate hybrid (on-prem + cloud) EKS/AKS platforms with GitOps (Argo CD + Helm), Karpenter, Terraform, and Kyverno, balancing reliability, security hardening, and cost control using Prometheus, Loki, Grafana, and OpenCost. On the MLOps side, I build Kubeflow + KServe‚Äìbased platforms for retraining and online inference, integrating MLflow and a feature store to support data scientists from experimentation to production. I enjoy mentoring engineers and sharing practical write-ups and talks on Kubernetes, GitOps, and data/ML platforms.

name: Rodolfo Campos
bio: I‚Äôm a technology enthusiast passionate about Artificial Intelligence, Software Development, DevSecOps and Cyber Security. Huge fan of Kubernetes and Kubeflow. I love to develop software, learn new things and automate workflows.

name: Rodrigo Bersa
bio: Rodrigo is a Specialist Solutions Architect with expertise in Containers, Security, and Infrastructure-as-Code. With around 20 years of experience with Linux and OSS, he has navigated various modernization journeys, from virtualization and hypervisors to containers and microservices orchestration. His focus since 2016, is on Kubernetes platforms, aiming to help the Cloud Native Community in events like KCD Washington D.C, Cloud Native NoVA and KubeCon, covering aspects related to strategies and best practices for operational excellence, security, and reliability using Open Source tools.

name: Rodrigo Correia De Sousa
bio: Works in Platform Engineering and SRE, focusing on the design, operation, and evolution of cloud-native environments based on Kubernetes, with over 18 years of experience in technology. Has experience with technologies across the CNCF ecosystem, working on reliability, observability, automation, security, and operational efficiency. Collaborates closely with engineering and architecture teams to evolve scalable platforms that support critical production workloads, promoting cloud-native best practices and standards.

name: Rodrigo Gon√ßalves Torres
bio: I am an AWS-certified Solutions Architect Professional, currently serving as an administrator for several on-premises Kubernetes clusters at a major oil company in Brazil. I have extensive knowledge in automating processes, particularly using Bash, Python, Terraform, and Ansible. Additionally, I work with GitOps, with a particular focus on Flux, and I am well-versed in using Helm.

name: Roeland Van De Pol
bio: I started with Kubernetes in 2014, did my first CKA in 2018 and I'm still going strong delivering the Kubernetes promise to enterprises around the world. I'm a technical architect. I like drafting designs on a whiteboard, presenting some nice slides to the execs and then whipping out a whole bunch of YAML code to make those designs into something to run your workloads. I also love delivering trainings. There is something magical to showing someone how they can just delete a pod and it "magically re-appears".

name: Rohan Rajguru
bio: I am a Linux and Open Source enthusiast, still new to Kubernetes and cloud-native, and I'm loving it! I enjoy implementing the tools and concepts I've learned. These days, I‚Äôve also started documenting my journey on LinkedIn and my blog. Let's connect!

name: Rohit Ghumare
bio:
Rohit Ghumare is a recognized Google Developer Expert in AI and Cloud, Docker Captain, Platform Ambassador, CNCF Marketing Chair 2025 a testament to his adeptness in contemporary cloud solutions. Contributed to Platform Engineer Associate exam and Certified Backstage Exam. He is the driving force behind several community-centric initiatives, orchestrating events as the organizer of KCD UK, Cloud Native Westminster London, DevOpsDays Bengaluru, KCD Mumbai, Google Cloud Mumbai, and the Cloud Native Thane community group. Through these platforms, he not only showcases his profound expertise but also fosters a collaborative ecosystem for knowledge exchange. A prolific writer, Rohit has authored a plethora of blogs and insightful pieces on CNCF projects, including, but not limited to, Backstage, Istio, Kubernetes, Cilium, Envoy, Prometheus, and Kiali. This extensive coverage underscores his profound understanding and engagement with cutting-edge cloud-native technologies. Besides penning down his knowledge, Rohit is dedicated to sharing his insights through the "Cloud Native Talks" podcast, which he hosts, and through global conferences and local meetups where he's presented multiple talks. He has also been a program committee member for Kubecon co-located events. Links: devopsguys.in

Why I am excited to be an ambassador: Being appointed as an ambassador presents a remarkable opportunity to further extend the outreach of my engagement within the tech community, particularly in the realms of DevOps and Cloud Native technologies. It will help me to give back to the community by sharing insights from experts located all over the world.

name: Rohit Kalva
bio: Cloud Architect, DevOps, and Site Reliability Engineer with 10+ years of experience architecting and scaling mission-critical enterprise infrastructure across AWS, GCP, and Azure platforms. I work with container orchestration, cloud-native solutions, AI/ML pipelines, and comprehensive SRE practices including observability and incident management. My focus areas include building resilient containerized environments, implementing DevSecOps practices, Infrastructure as Code, GitOps methodologies, and designing fault-tolerant distributed systems. I'm passionate about open source projects and the Kubernetes ecosystem, and enjoy contributing to the community through shared knowledge and collaborative innovation.

name: Rohit Ramteke
bio: Part time Cloud Engineer, Full time Gamer

name: Roland Rust
bio: With a background in software development and system architecture, I understand the importance of reliable and scalable infrastructure platforms. As a Site Reliability Engineer, I focus on building and operating highly available hybrid cloud environments. My expertise includes managing multiple Kubernetes clusters and diverse infrastructure components using infrastructure-as-code practices. I am dedicated to empowering development teams through efficient GitOps workflows and am passionate about monitoring and metrics to ensure optimal system performance and resiliency. I strive to bridge the gap between development and operations, driving continuous improvement across the organization.

name: Romain Ballan
bio: I am a Senior Site Reliability Engineer working on cloud-native platforms with a cloud-agnostic mindset. I design, build, and operate reliable, scalable systems by applying modern engineering practices. I rely on industry standards, with a strong focus on long-term maintainability and operational quality.

name: Romain Boulanger
bio: Eternally passionate and deeply curious, I‚Äôve always enjoyed learning on my own, particularly anything to do with automation, containerisation and IT security. I‚Äôm also a big fan of open-source technologies, which I experiment with on a daily basis as I set up my own infrastructure to host my personal blog: blog.filador.ch. With a rate of one article a month, I love sharing what I discover! Finally, I‚Äôve had the opportunity to work with several cloud providers: Google Cloud, AWS, Azure and even AliCloud. If you ask me the question, ‚ÄúWhich one do you prefer?‚Äù I‚Äôd answer that it depends on your use case! Since 2024, I‚Äôve been an Ambassador for the Silicon Chalet. This Meetup brings together a community of over 1,600 members from Switzerland and France! My role is to promote tools and approaches close to my heart, either by organising events or by presenting topics.

name: Romain Decker
bio: Romain is a Group Product Manager at Spectro Cloud. He has 20+ years of diverse work experience in architecture, consulting, and technical product management. Throughout his career, he has worked for a variety of organizations, including hosting companies, enterprises, EU institutions, and system integrators.

name: Ronit Banerjee

Along with my academics, I have maintained a strong portfolio being an Open Source Developer at the projects incubated and graduated from The Linux Foundation and Cloud Native Computing Foundation. My enthusiasm with DevOps and Cloud Native helped me to secure scholarships like Travel Funding Scholarship and Dan Kohn Scholarship by The Linux Foundation and Cloud Native Computing Foundation to attend flagship conferences such as KubeCon + CloudNativeCon + Open Source Summit China 2023 at Shanghai and Open Source Summit Europe 2022 at Dublin. I also worked as an Open Source Developer in Google Summer of Code (GSoC) at DBpedia Association. Apart from my technical experience, I got my hands dirty in fostering the Cloud Native Ecosystem. I am also the Chapter Lead at Cloud Native Hooghly which is an official CNCF Chapter listed amongst 40 such clubs in the Asia Pacific Region. Right now, with the proliferation of the Cloud Native Tools, I successfully turned the chapter to be the fastest growing in the entire Eastern India, catering 250+ Active members. I am also a Sig Contribex's Comms Volunteer for Kubernetes Contributors Summit North America 2023 at Chicago, United States of America primarily looking into the ‚ÄúCall for Proposal‚Äù emails and notifying about the updates to the KubeCon co-located event attendees. I have significant experience in pitching tech products to Venture Capitalists and have successfully secured grants from Government of India twice for my deep-tech startup.

Why I am excited to be an ambassador: I always wanted to boost Cloud Native Ecosystem in my locality whereas I felt there is a gap of awareness. Being an ambassador, it would really help me to reach areas where I couldn't do by myself just being a CNCG chapter lead of Hooghly. With CNCF's support it would be possible.

Why I am excited to be an ambassador: I am excited to be an ambassador because I'm getting to connect with lots of great people across all of the CNCF projects to make the cloud native ecosystem better. In my ambassadorship year, my goals are to take the great speakers we are cultivating in the observability community and help place them in as many general cloud native meetups as possible to spread the word about cloud native observability, to start a streaming series where we work with different CNCF projects to instrument them, and to get the word out about the end user work we've been doing within OpenTelemetry so other projects can better serve end users.

All that apart, I'm music-passionate and a restless shower performer, a winter couch knitter and cat cuddler, a balcony gardening ace, a dabble baker, and a great backwarmer during adventurous motorcycle journeys.

Why I am excited to be an ambassador: Being a non-tech member and a proud CNCF ambassador, I'm determined to lend my support in any way possible. His published paper, which received the Best Paper Award at IEEE SOLI 2021, can be accessed at: "ASIST: Automated Strategic Partners Ranking and Recommendation System Using NLP and Security Intelligence," 2021 IEEE International Conference on Service Operations and Logistics, and Informatics (SOLI), 2021 (https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/9672369).

My passion for this cause has led me to actively participate in various initiatives, such as organizing the Cloud Native Luxembourg meetups and being part of the French localization team of CNCF Glossary. I'm dedicated to promoting the benefits of open-source software, believing it to be more secure, reliable, and conducive to innovation. Additionally, I leverage my expertise to help teams harness cloud-native technologies, fostering a culture of collaboration and continuous improvement.

Why I am excited to be an ambassador: Drawing from my passion for open-source, I will strive to promote the ethos of collaboration, emphasizing the merits of open-source projects within the CNCF landscape and encouraging more entities to contribute and participate. I am committed to guiding the next generation of cloud native enthusiasts. Through mentorship programs and hands-on training sessions, I aim to reduce the learning curve for newcomers and ensure they have the necessary tools and knowledge to thrive within the ecosystem. In essence, as a CNCF Ambassador, my overarching goal is to be a catalyst for growth, learning, and innovation within the Cloud Native community, ensuring that it remains at the forefront of technological progress while upholding the values of collaboration, inclusivity, and open-source spirit.
